awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Designing Next Generation Digital Employment and Recruitment Intervention Tools: Identifying Technical Features to Support Underserved Job Seekers in the U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to understand the requirements for and to begin building next-generation information technology tools and applications that address the distinct needs of underserved U.S. job seekers, who live in low-socioeconomic regions, have limited education, or have low income. Many of today's technologies facilitate the needs of relatively affluent populations with very limited consideration of the needs of underserved populations. This leads to offline inequality of opportunity transferring to online means of job application. As a result, underserved job seekers may lack the confidence, skills, and economic means necessary to make use of mainstream technologies used to support the employment process. They face obstacles such as articulating job skills and using these skills to develop resumes, developing educational pathways to gain needed job skills, and giving a successful interview. As non-technical employers and companies increase their use of mainstream online recruitment and interviewing tools, the digital recruitment divide may widen and exacerbate the employment plight of underserved populations, unless research like this project finds ways to mitigate the problems and adapt information technology to serve the needs of this significant part of the workforce.  This study will fill a gap in the research on the challenges of using digital recruitment and employment tools among underserved populations and will ultimately lead to better digital employment and recruitment software.

This project will apply the Theory of Planned Behavior as a perspective and guide for evaluating digital employment applications. The research results will expand the theory to include digital barriers and constraints faced by underserved job seekers and stakeholders such as managers and staff at job centers who support them. Well-known human-computer interaction methods will be used to iteratively build and enhance three alternative digital employment and recruitment applications to evaluate their impact on job search attitudes, subjective norms (or social support) and perceived behavioral control (or self-efficacy) - all factors that could lead to job attainment. These applications are: (1) SkillsExtractor, a proof-of-concept prototype that uses an open dataset provided by the Open Skills Project to extract and identify job skills from past job title searches; (2) Interview4, an existing non-mainstream tool that enables job seekers to conduct mock interviews and send these interviews to friends for feedback; and (3) Review-Me, a pilot application that the research team built, deployed, and evaluated to enlist social support by connecting job seekers to volunteers for resume review. This project will conclude with an effort to evaluate the tools as well as to identify and report challenges that would benefit from policy intervention. This research will provide important theoretical insights about what technical features are effective and ineffective in underserved populations, and why.

por.por_cntn:
Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) have the potential to support job searches and resume creation. Social media technologies allow us to highlight employment skills and share employment opportunities with friends and family. These online resources are now as necessary as offline professional and personal networks, which have been critical to the employment search. Yet, ICTs advantage higher-income job seekers with higher education levels. They could better support job seekers without advanced degrees. They could also better support those whose demographics reflect those of the highest unemployment groups in the U.S. (i.e., racial minorities, women, people with disabilities, and lower-income individuals). To better understand how such technologies could more equitably support these groups, we have used qualitative and quantitative human-computer interaction approaches to reach more than 800 job seekers and stakeholders. Approaches include participatory design and participatory action research, surveys and interviews, technological field deployments, and evaluation. Most of our research has focused on job seekers' perspectives. Yet, we also conducted in-depth interviews with external stakeholders, including career counselors, job training center employees, and recruiters. This gave us a more comprehensive and holistic understanding of the employment process among job seekers experiencing marginalization.

Early empirical results suggested that job seekers have limited access to social networks that provide: immediate job search feedback (i.e., from resumes and interviews); mentorship and information about employment opportunities; assistance to help underserved job seekers articulate the skills they have acquired from past jobs; and transportation to interviews or job training sites. Building on these results, we developed three tools. (1) Review-Me is a tool to provide job seekers with resume feedback via crowdsourcing. (2) SkillsIdentifier is a tool to help job seekers identify and articulate their existing skillsets from past employment. (3) Review-Me is a tool to provide job seekers with a pathway to reach their dream jobs. We conducted an 8-month randomized field experiment to evaluate Review-Me alongside an existing Interview feedback tool, Interview4, with 23 job seekers. Our goal was to assess whether the tools addressed job seekers' feedback needs. We used the Theory of Planned Behavior as a framework to examine the tools' effects on three factors influencing job seekers' job search intention: job search self-efficacy, subjective norms, and job search attitudes. Interview results suggest that the tools positively affected all factors. Positive feedback and self-reflection drove these trends.  We evaluated SkillsIdentifier with 20 Midwestern U.S. job seekers. SkillsIdentifier helped job seekers find words to describe their skills and raise awareness of their career identity, which fostered self-efficacy. SkillsIdentifier also helped job seekers understand their soft skills, which they had not considered sharing before in their resumes or interviews. In our evaluation of DreamGigs, we conducted a series of design sprints with 25 social workers and job seekers to develop DreamGigs. DreamGigs motivated job seekers to stay engaged in their search. The tool also expanded their career opportunities by sharing new paths to their ideal job. Participating in the agile and iterative design and development of DreamGigs empowered job seekers.  In summary, job seekers would value the creation of tech tools to provide application feedback, clarify the skills needed to secure desired employment and where to get those skills, and have opportunities to design tools alongside developers. 

To understand the generalizability of our findings, we conducted an online survey of 768 U.S. job seekers. We investigated specific online resources that were key to employment. We also investigated which online platforms, distinct job search phases, behaviors, and strategies they used in their job search. To understand the factors associated with positive outcomes, we examined whether these results correlated with demographic characteristics. Results suggest differences in online platform use among income, gender, years of education, and race. Higher-income job seekers were more likely to use different strategies and get callbacks than lower-income job seekers. 

Together, our results identified ways socioeconomic inequality across demographic groups persists in online contexts. Thus, we can not expect all digital employment tools to serve all populations equally. Practitioners must rethink how perceptions of design might lead to divisions in thinking and exclusion in usage.  Employers' use of social media and other online platforms for hiring might bias the job search process. Such bias could lead to persistent inequities in hiring. Designers and employment advocates should innovate to create applications to meet marginalized job seekers' needs in the job search process. 

Besides scientific and policy publications, this research provided training and experience to 22 trainees. Job seekers reported becoming more self-reflective as a by-product of the research. Some of the methods used empowered them. Additionally, the interview gave job seekers emotional support. By listening to job seekers, participants felt heard. They felt as if someone cared about their circumstances.
